msgSnippet: ... Did those teams reach the point where end-to-end tests took more than overnight to run? When that happens, I see teams starting to cherry- pick their
messageBody:
On Feb 26, 2008, at 03:22 , Nat Pryce wrote:

> On 26/02/2008, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains762@...> wrote:
> > It's only my opinion, but what I observe teams writing some end-to-
> end
> > tests, but not nearly enough, and finding some integration defects,
> > but not nearly enough.
>
> That certainly tallies with my experience.
>
> > I believe that the less we rely on end-to-end tests, the less we'd
> > allow ourselves to duplicate high-level structures, and therefore
> the
> > fewer integration defects we'd have. This would make end-to-end
> tests
> > all the less valuable.
>
> I've found the opposite. Many times I've seen teams do "TDD" but only
> write unit tests. They had integration problems that were only
> brought under control when they started writing end-to-end tests.
>
Did those teams reach the point where end-to-end tests took more than
overnight to run? When that happens, I see teams starting to cherry-
pick their end-to-end tests, writing only the easy ones that are
likely already to pass, and that's the point at which integration
defects leak in by the ton.
